data.title: Guides and Galleries
data.text: This is the hub of the historic Blackstone Corridor. Across the street from Slater Mill, it's a great place to start exploring the region. In addition to tons of literature for where to go, it has a theater and two art galleries. full disclosure: My photographs of Havana are currently hanging in Gallery175.

data.title: Spacious visitor center
data.text: Come to the visitor's center to see a 20 minute orientation film.  Nice video.  We were told that the seats were quite old.  They were quite comfortable.  Lot's of brochures are available and the woman behind the counter was extremely friendly, knowledgeable and helpful.  There was also a small art gallery inside.  It's right next to public transit and across the street from the Slater Mill Museum.   Ample free parking is also available.

data.title: So helpful!
data.text: We stopped here after visiting Slater Mill across the street. We were looking for National Park cancellation stamps for our passport books. (They have them!) They had closed there doors moments before but the woman on duty re-opened for us. (Bathrooms were also a necessary part of the stop!) She was so accommodating! Not only did she let us use the restroom, but she also spent 10 minutes with us talking about the area to make sure we'd seen everything we would be interested in! We'll definitely be coming through again!

data.title: Right across the street from the Old Slater Mill.
data.text: This visitors center is located on a corner and the address given, while it maybe the front of the building, is not the main entrance to the visitors center. The entrance to the visitors center and the parking lot is around the corner. This building used to be a large department store which went out of business. This review is based on what we experienced and not what is the "norm".  We happened to visit the morning after they had rented out the space for some event and when we walked in everything was covered with black drapes and there was nobody around.  We noticed a map on the floor and went over to look at it.  While we were looking a woman came to an area in the center of the large room that had counters set in a circle with space in the middle for "workers".  She had several pamphlets in her hands and was trying to get everything put back together.  She explained why the place looked like it did and offered to show us the video which played in a corner room set up for that purpose.  The theatre seats were from a historic building.  The video was worth the time to see.  When we left everything was still covered in black drapes so I'm not sure what the place would look like and offer on a normal visit.

owner_response.author: TourBlackstoneValley, Manager at Blackstone Valley Visitor Center, responded to this review
owner_response.text:
Hi Saxeygirl, 
Thank you so much for visiting us in Blackstone Valley and for writing this review. We've made changes to our listing to better reflect where parking and entrance to the visitor center is. We're sorry if that caused any confusion. 
With regard to the drapes, you are correct that those are not normally there. Visiting us at almost any other time and you would see a large-scale timeline of Blackstone Valley's history from William Blackstone and Samuel Slater, to the growth in population and factories, and our current National Park and mill redevelopment. In addition to being a visitor center, the space is also used as a unique alternative event space and those drapes were put up during an event just the night before. We are going to make it a heightened point to make sure that doesn't happen again. 
Thanks again, and hope to see you again around Blackstone Valley, Rhode Island's National Park.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Great local visitor center
data.text: The Blackstone Valley Visitor Center is a really nice facility that has good information about the sites, scenes and adventures offered in the Blackstone Valley.  They have a cute little gift shop featuring local artists work that is available at reasonable costs...for that local flavor.

data.title: Very Nice
data.text: If your traveling through Pawtucket RI then you would want to stop at the visitors center.  They have maps,brochures, bathroom sink and many interesting facts about Blackstone Valley.  There's a movie you can watch and the Old Slater Mill is across the street.   Great staff as well.

data.title: Good spot to stop for history and attractions
data.text: The visitor center builds off of some of the history that you can see at the Slater Mill museum right across the street and has a few displays that are interesting to read. There is also pamphlets of things to do in the area and the whole Blackstone Valley. It's worth the stop to see what is out there and definitely worth it if you have gone to the Slater Mill.

data.title: Good collection of info here
data.text: I come here every so often when I'm getting out-of-town visitors and need some ideas for what to show them. Always some new ideas here. This is also the venue for the Pawtucket Film Festival in September, always worth a visit for us locals.

data.title: Pleasant time on a Sunday afternoon
data.text: We live near by but had never visited.  We were warmly welcomed and given a brief personal tour, and preparatory remarks for the video.  The informative displays and the video are a great preparation for the museum across the street.  The room size map on the floor was neat and gave us perspective on what else is around us as we found where our home sits in the Blackstone Valley.

data.title: a great place to visit and to get info you will need.
data.text: a great venue for finding out about a very historical area of the USA. So much started in this area that you should see it as a part of History. New England at its Best. From Slater Mill where the textile industry started in Pawt.RI.on to many other interesting locations.

data.title: Well worth a visit
data.text: Worth visiting . The lady in charge Wendy was very helpful and enthusiastic. The film she showed us was informative and gave a better grasp of the area and its origins .

data.title: Haunted Riverride
data.text: We went on the Halloween Haunted Riverride, it was a different experience.  Not very scary.   We did learn some history of the area.

data.title: A Real Treasure
data.text: We were pleasantly surprised by the wealth of information in this visitors center.  The person in charge, I think her name was Wendy, was so friendly and so helpful!  The video that was shown was a real eye-opener into the history of the area, particularly the growth and eventual demise of the textile industry.  They also have a nicely stocked gift shop with Rhode Island specialty items like Dave's Coffee Syrup.  To find this on MapQuest, search Blackstone Valley Tourism Council Inc, 175 Main St., Pawtucket, RI 02860

data.title: Info
data.text: If you're looking for things to do in and around Pawtucket, they can help. Pamphlets and maps and bus schedules.

data.title: Free.  Worth a stop
data.text: Very helpful staff person - information, brochures and maps.  Also a very well-done short movie on Slater Mill is well worth the time.

data.title: Wonderful Visitors Center
data.text: When in New England, this RI Visitors Center is a place to see.  Lovely interior with lots of informational brochures for local attractions, restaurants and places to stay. It is located just across the street from the historic Old Slater Mill in Pawtucket, RI.

data.title: Great Bicycle Tour of the Blackstone Valley
data.text: We toured the Blackstone Valley by bike.  What a great time!!!  The tour leader, Bob Billington, the Tour leader, is knowledgable, considerate, and very low key.  The trip brings riders through some of the city streets that showcase the history of the industrial revolution in the USA.  You'll tour the historic Blackstone River and see a variety of mills that buzzed during their peak.  You stop at ethnic food stores and textile mills to see how the valley is still producing despite economic and demographic changes.  You'll visit small mill villages and then head on to stunning scenery in Cumberland and Lincoln RI.  The ride is very leisurely and I'd recommend it for all but the youngest children and the very oldest adults.
